questions.text: The below image shows a retrograde uretero-pyelogram of a patient with loin pain. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Hydronephrosis The retrograde pyelogram shows ureteropelvic junction and hydronephrosis (aseptic dilatation of the kidney caused by obstruction), representing dilated clubbed calyces and a greatly enlarged pelvis.

Highyeild:

IMAGING IN HYDRONEPHROSIS Isotope renography (DTPA -Diethylenetriamine penta-acetic acid) or MAG-3 (Mercaptoacetyltriglycine) injected intravenously is the best test to confirm the obstructive dilatation of the collecting system. IVU (intravenous urogram) helps only if the obstructed kidney functions significantly. In IVU the extrarenal pelvis dilated and the minor calyces lose their normal cupping and become clubbed. Management: Anderson-Hynes operation, endoscopic pyelolysis.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Duplex kidney is a developmental condition in which one or both kidneys have 2 ureter tubes to drain urine rather than a single tube. Option: C. Renal carcinoma is depicted with abnormal calcification and distortion of renal outline. The calyces are distorted. Very commonly secondaries in chest X-rays are seen. Option: D. Renal stones can be seen as discrete opacities easily seen on KUB. A branched stone is unmistakable.

Extraedge:

Prenatal fetal hydronephrosis often resolves under observation alone Ultrasound scan is an excellent method to detect hydronephrosis

The patient also had palpitations, weakness and fatigue frequently. Which of the following stones is suspected in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ammonium urate The history is suggestive of laxative abuse. The clinical features are that of Hypokalaemia In laxative abuse, there is excess potassium loss due to which the kidney starts producing large amounts of ammonium causing ammonium urate stones

questions.text: A 30-year- male presents with complaints of abdominal pain radiating from loin to groin, intermittent, no aggravating or relieving factor, no history of haematuria, no history of abdominal distention or fever. X-ray KUB is given below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: B. Left lower pole renal calculi
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Left lower pole renal calculi A radio-opaque shadow is seen in the lower pole of the left kidney. Probably a calculi

Highyeild:

Imaging of Ureteric Colic (Calculus) A plain film of the abdomen and renal ultrasound examination will diagnose most stones. A non-opaque stone (uric acid) will be seen as a radiolucent defect in the opaque contrast media Spiral CT (Non-contrast CT) has become the study of choice in emergent situations, as the entire urinary tract can be scanned rapidly and without contrast injection. Excretory urography is necessary to verify their location within the urinary tract and gives a qualitative measure of renal function. About 90% of calculi are radiopaque (calcium, cystine). An acutely obstructed kidney may show only increasing density of renal shadow without significant radiopaque material in calyces. Calculi can be readily identified and distinguished from clots or tumours.

questions.text: A 40-year male presented to OPD with complaints of right abdominal pain for 1 week, no haematuria, vomiting, or abdominal distention. On examination, right lumbar tenderness was present, with no guarding or rigidity. CT abdomen showed 1.4cm renal calculi along the lower pole of the right kidney. What is the best treatment of choice?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

ESWL ESWL is the common form of treatment these days for renal calculi and stones up to 1.5cm is suitable for this form of treatment

Highyeild:

ESWL(Extracorporeal Shockwave Lithotripsy) SWL is a non-invasive method that allows stones to be treated on an outpatient basis. Mechanism of action The stone is localised using either fluoroscopy or the US or both. Then acoustic pulse waves are generated and focused on the stone. Stone fragmentation occurs as a result of mechanical stress caused directly by the energy transmitted by the incident shockwave and indirectly by the collapse of bubbles. The efficacy of SWL reduces with an increasing number of stones and volume of stone burden.

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Conservative treatment can be tried for stones <0.5cm/5mm Option: C. Is indicated in anatomical abnormalities Calyceal diverticula Ureteric obstruction Obese patients in whom ESWL is contraindicated Lower calyceal stone

questions.text: A 35-year female diagnosed with renal calculi of 1.5cm size, was referred to a urologist for further management. The urologist suggests ESWL for this patient as the management. Which of the following is not a contraindication for ESWL?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cystine stone CYSTINE stones are relatively resistant to ESWL due to their hardness but are not contraindicated

Highyeild:

EXTRACORPOREAL SHOCKWAVE LITHOTRIPSY (ESWL, ESL) : This is a non-invasive method of treating urinary tract stones by generating shockwaves outside the body which are focused on the stones. It was first used on humans in Germany in 1980. Different methods of generating shock waves include spark gap, electromagnetic, piezoelectric and micro-expulsive. Shockwaves generated using the spark-gap method need to be coordinated with the patient’s electrocardiogram (ECG) to prevent cardiac arrhythmias. Stones can be localised for treatment using either fluoroscopy or USS. This is the common form of treatment these days for renal calculi and stones up to approximately 1.5 cm in size are suitable for this form of treatment. More than one treatment session maybe needed to fully treat the stone, especially if it is sizeable. Prophylactic antibiotics are used to prevent infection as stones are often colonised by bacteria. Cystine stones are relatively resistant to ESWL due to their hardness. In addition to infection, ESWL may result in haematuria, parenchymal haemorrhage and even perirenal haematoma. A collection of stone fragments in a ureter after ESWL for a significant renal stone is given the German name of steinstrasse (‘street of stones’). Contraindications to ESWL are obese patients, pregnant patients and patients taking oral anticoagulants.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Options: A, B & D. Obese patients, pregnancies and patients on anticoagulants are absolute contraindications of ESWL

Extraedge:

The efficacy of SWL reduces with an increasing number of stones and volume of stone burden. Steinstrasse is a German word meaning ‘ street of stones ’. It describes a row of closely gathered stone fragments that line the distal end of the ureter These stones are usually asymptomatic and pass spontaneously ; however, they may cause obstruction, requiring surgical intervention.
